issue.title: Gazebo 2.2.3 Broke Simulation Stability / Regression from 2.2.2

content.raw: And the 2.2.2 debs are no longer here: http://packages.osrfoundation.org/gazebo/ubuntu/pool/main/g/gazebo-current/ so I have to build it from source. Also what happened to all of the content on the old Gazebo wiki? There's a ton of stuff missing from the new bitbucket one.
content.html: And the 2.2.2 debs are no longer here: http://packages.osrfoundation.org/gazebo/ubuntu/pool/main/g/gazebo-current/ so I have to build it from source. Also what happened to all of the content on the old Gazebo wiki? There's a ton of stuff missing from the new bitbucket one.

issue.title: Gazebo 2.2.3 Broke Simulation Stability / Regression from 2.2.2

content.raw:
About the old packages, repositories usually do not keep the old versions. Probably our [assets directory](http://old.gazebosim.org/assets/distributions/) can help you to find the old packages that you are looking for.

About the regression, it would be nice to have more information about what is failing and it would be great to have a reproducible case. And indeed, regressions in patch releases are a pain, this is why we only accept changes that fix a known issue in patch releases. Unfortunately changes can always hide bugs.

About the wiki content, please let us know what is missing.
content.html:
About the old packages, repositories usually do not keep the old versions. Probably our assets directory can help you to find the old packages that you are looking for.

About the regression, it would be nice to have more information about what is failing and it would be great to have a reproducible case. And indeed, regressions in patch releases are a pain, this is why we only accept changes that fix a known issue in patch releases. Unfortunately changes can always hide bugs.

About the wiki content, please let us know what is missing.

issue.title: Gazebo 2.2.3 Broke Simulation Stability / Regression from 2.2.2

content.raw:
I suspect the instability might be due to this pull request #1125. Previously, ODE may have over-inflated the diagonal terms of the constraint matrix yielding incorrect physics. We patched it to be more physically correct, but also less stable.

tagging @scpeters

Sorry about that @jbohren, for now, if you can't revert to 2.2.2, the correct thing to do is to increase the number of inner iterations `<iters>`.

Is your model open? Can we take a look at how it's failing?
content.html:
I suspect the instability might be due to this pull request #1125. Previously, ODE may have over-inflated the diagonal terms of the constraint matrix yielding incorrect physics. We patched it to be more physically correct, but also less stable.

tagging @scpeters

Sorry about that @jbohren, for now, if you can't revert to 2.2.2, the correct thing to do is to increase the number of inner iterations <iters>.

Is your model open? Can we take a look at how it's failing?

issue.title: Gazebo 2.2.3 Broke Simulation Stability / Regression from 2.2.2
Gazebo 2.2.3 Broke Simulation Stability / Regression from 2.2.2

content.raw:
> I suspect the instability might be due to this pull request #1125. Previously, ODE may have over-inflated the diagonal terms of the constraint matrix yielding incorrect physics. We patched it to be more physically correct, but also less stable.
tagging Steven Peters

That sounds like it might be it. Could you add that to the changelog? This sort of change really affects people who had tuned their simulation to work in one way or another.

> Sorry about that Jonathan Bohren, for now, if you can't revert to 2.2.2, the correct thing to do is to increase the number of inner iterations <iters>.
> Is your model open? Can we take a look at how it's failing?

Yeah, it's open, but I can try adjusting the inner iterations, myself. For now I'm just using 2.2.2 from source.

Building gazebo from source in my workspace was made pretty simple thanks to https://github.com/catkin/catkin_tools, it just meant an unexpected hour of downtime to make sure that was the only thing that changed and then another half hour to rebuild my workspcae.

@hsu @_jrivero_ Thanks for responding to this so fast.
content.html:
I suspect the instability might be due to this pull request #1125. Previously, ODE may have over-inflated the diagonal terms of the constraint matrix yielding incorrect physics. We patched it to be more physically correct, but also less stable. tagging Steven Peters

That sounds like it might be it. Could you add that to the changelog? This sort of change really affects people who had tuned their simulation to work in one way or another.

Sorry about that Jonathan Bohren, for now, if you can't revert to 2.2.2, the correct thing to do is to increase the number of inner iterations <iters>. Is your model open? Can we take a look at how it's failing?

Yeah, it's open, but I can try adjusting the inner iterations, myself. For now I'm just using 2.2.2 from source.

Building gazebo from source in my workspace was made pretty simple thanks to https://github.com/catkin/catkin_tools, it just meant an unexpected hour of downtime to make sure that was the only thing that changed and then another half hour to rebuild my workspcae.

@hsu @jrivero Thanks for responding to this so fast.

issue.title: Gazebo 2.2.3 Broke Simulation Stability / Regression from 2.2.2

content.raw:
Also I'm seeing situations where sometimes one of these "inertias" is negative.

I added the following on quickstep.cpp:1576
```
printf("WARNING: Large inertia ratio detected: %g / %g > %g\n", m_large, m_small, moi_ratio_max);
```

And saw this (After I increased `moi_ratio_max` to `2e+7`):

```
WARNING: Large inertia ratio detected: 0.000298256 / -1.00949e-07 > 2e+07
WARNING: Large inertia ratio detected: 0.000389571 / -1.63706e-05 > 2e+07
```
content.html:
Also I'm seeing situations where sometimes one of these "inertias" is negative.

I added the following on quickstep.cpp:1576

printf("WARNING: Large inertia ratio detected: %g / %g > %g\n", m_large, m_small, moi_ratio_max);

And saw this (After I increased moi_ratio_max to 2e+7):

WARNING: Large inertia ratio detected: 0.000298256 / -1.00949e-07 > 2e+07
WARNING: Large inertia ratio detected: 0.000389571 / -1.63706e-05 > 2e+07

issue.title: Gazebo 2.2.3 Broke Simulation Stability / Regression from 2.2.2

content.raw: @hsu I think there are way too many FIXMEs and TODOs in this dynamic inertia ratio stuff. I've created a PR which disables this until it can be properly tested: #!/osrf/gazebo/pull-request/1219/opende-disabling-dynamic-moi-rescaling-by/diff
content.html: @hsu I think there are way too many FIXMEs and TODOs in this dynamic inertia ratio stuff. I've created a PR which disables this until it can be properly tested: #!/osrf/gazebo/pull-request/1219/opende-disabling-dynamic-moi-rescaling-by/diff

issue.title: Gazebo 2.2.3 Broke Simulation Stability / Regression from 2.2.2

content.raw:
Note that despite adding support to disable the feature which breaks some simulations [1], this is still broken in Gazebo>=2.2.3 without dynamically linking against libsdformat >= 1.4.12, which will not be released to the debian repositories [2].

* [1] #!/osrf/gazebo/pull-request/1277/physics-actually-using-new/diff
* [2] https://bitbucket.org/osrf/sdformat/commits/0cd3ae72d7e24c49eeb1c2990d86248df44976f9#comment-1456565
content.html:
Note that despite adding support to disable the feature which breaks some simulations [1], this is still broken in Gazebo>=2.2.3 without dynamically linking against libsdformat >= 1.4.12, which will not be released to the debian repositories [2].

  • [1] #!/osrf/gazebo/pull-request/1277/physics-actually-using-new/diff
  • [2] https://bitbucket.org/osrf/sdformat/commits/0cd3ae72d7e24c49eeb1c2990d86248df44976f9#comment-1456565
